<summary>
• The discussion centered on the targeted funding to improve educational outcomes, specifically focusing on the pupil development grant (PDG).
• The PDG is aimed at targeting resources more widely than just those eligible for free school meals, with a focus on low-attaining free-school-meal pupils and those who are more able and talented.
• There is a concern about the targeting of the PDG, with some evidence suggesting a blurring of eligibility and a focus beyond free-school-meal pupils.
• The PDG is used to drive attainment for more able and talented students, including those eligible for PDG, through initiatives like the 'window on the world' bus in Pembrokeshire.
• The eligibility for free school meals is considered the best proxy for identifying students to target, but there is ongoing consideration of alternative measures.
• There is a push for greater flexibility in PDG allocation, allowing for longer-term projections and potentially targeting more students, though this would require additional funding.
• The PDG is used to support attendance and engagement, with examples of schools employing strategies like walking buses to address attendance issues.
• The impact of PDG on attainment has seen a widening of the gap in 2017, despite previous narrowing trends, with discussions ongoing about the reasons behind this.
• The attainment gap for looked-after children remains disappointing, with the PDG regionalized to support strategic deployment of resources.
• Lessons from Schools Challenge Cymru are being applied to the wider school improvement agenda, focusing on leadership, systems, teacher quality, and collaborative activity.
• The transition from Schools Challenge Cymru to the regional consortia has been managed, with key staff transferring to continue their work on a regional basis.
</summary>

<summary>
• The group believes that the EAS consortium's approach to using the looked-after and adopted PDG as part of a broader approach targeted at vulnerable learners is effective. 
• The majority of schools are making well thought out and appropriate decisions on how to use the PDG, as indicated by Estyn's reports. However, only two-thirds of primary and secondary schools are making effective use of the PDG, suggesting room for improvement.
• The PDG is being used to address various issues, such as improving attendance, reducing exclusions, and supporting vulnerable learners. For instance, schools are employing staff to work directly with families of older children to reinforce attendance messages.
• The impact of PDG on attainment is complex. While there is a direction of travel towards narrowing the gap, the 2017 attainment gap widened. Factors such as the move from BTECs to science GCSEs and the unintended consequences of literature on performance are being considered as potential reasons for the change.
</summary>

<summary>
• The draft strategy aims to address overweight and obesity issues among all ages, with a strong focus on children and young people.
• Dr Frank Atherton is confident in the strategy's ability to deliver for children and young people, emphasizing the importance of prevention.
• Engagement with children and young people has been conducted through various forums, including a school visit and consultation sessions.
• The Minister for health advised that Dr Atherton provided advice not to set a target for reducing childhood obesity, but that a target may still be considered.
• The level of investment needed to implement the plan is uncertain, with a potential range of PS8 million to PS10 million per year being discussed.
• The sugar levy's consequentials are less than anticipated, with PS56 million over two years being the current estimate.
• The strategy emphasizes partnership working across sectors, including government, health, education, and industry, to drive change.
• Leadership and oversight are crucial, with a national implementation board accountable to Ministers expected to drive the strategy forward.
• Data collection is acknowledged as a gap, with the child measurement programme being the main source of information on childhood obesity.
• The plan considers expanding the child measurement programme to include a second measurement, aiming to better understand the progression of obesity.
• The draft plan commits to reviewing the clinical obesity pathway, with Public Health Wales tasked to conduct the review before the strategy's finalization in October.
</summary>

• The meeting discussed ongoing research projects related to speech processing and recognition.
  1. Dave presented on implementing mean log magnitude spectral subtraction for the SmartKom system, testing different window lengths for mean calculation. He found that using twelve seconds of past data slightly reduced performance compared to a centered window, but the difference was minimal.
  2. Sunil shared his work on single-stage Wiener filtering, which improved baseline performance by about 30% but did not surpass 50% improvement over the baseline. He explored using the channel zero VAD for noise estimation, which showed better results than using the current VAD.
  3. Stephane discussed spectral subtraction techniques, including an overestimation factor to estimate noise and subtract it from the signal spectrum. He applied smoothing to the gain trajectory to reduce musical noise, achieving better results on Italian but worse on Finnish compared to previous methods.
  4. The group discussed the use of smoothing techniques in spectral subtraction and Wiener filtering to mitigate issues like musical noise. It was noted that smoothing can help reduce noise but may not always improve recognition performance.
  5. The team considered the impact of using different noise compensation techniques on overall system performance, with discussions on the effectiveness of spectral subtraction, Wiener filtering, and subspace approaches.

* The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) has observed a decrease in EU student applications to Welsh institutions.
  * The decrease contrasts with a 2% increase in England, possibly due to changes in student support arrangements for EU students.
  * HEFCW is monitoring the situation closely, awaiting the actual recruitment data.
  * The decrease in EU and international student applications is also attributed to a downturn in the 18-year-old school-leaver profile.
  * The Welsh sector is facing pressures on funding, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, and capital expenditure.
  * The HEFCW is working with the sector to strengthen marketing efforts and differentiate the strengths of studying in Wales.
  * The sector is also focusing on making arguments to the UK Government for maintaining access to funding sources like Horizon 2020.

<summary>
• The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) is responsible for funding provision in Welsh higher education institutions.
• Brexit has led to uncertainty about the impact on the sector, particularly regarding funding sources from the EU, such as student fees, structural funds, and research funding.
• There has been a decrease in applications from EU students to Welsh institutions, contrasting with an increase in England.
• The decrease in EU student applications may be due to changes in student support arrangements for EU students and the perception of the UK as a whole.
• The Welsh higher education sector is facing pressures including funding, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, capital expenditure, and the potential impact of the Augar review on fees and funding in England.
• The HEFCW is monitoring the financial forecasts of institutions and is awaiting updated information on recruitment and enrolments.
• Institutions are planning for various scenarios, including Brexit impacts, and are looking for additional sources of funding, such as strengthening marketing efforts and making arguments to the UK government for maintaining access to EU funding sources.
• The HEFCW is working with the Welsh Government's HE Brexit group to inform policy decisions and discussions with the UK government.
• The sector is also focusing on promoting and protecting student interests, particularly in terms of mobility and immigration status of EU students.
• The HEFCW has a statutory duty to assess academic quality and is concerned about potential impacts on quality from Brexit, including the richness of the student experience and adherence to European quality standards.
• The HEFCW has provided information on the financial impact of Brexit on the sector, including the potential need for transition funding, and has advised the Welsh Government on this matter.
</summary>

* The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) has identified several key pressures on the Welsh higher education sector.
  * Funding position is the main pressure, with the implementation of Sir Ian Diamond's recommendations for re-establishing funding for higher education institutions taking longer than expected.
  * EU student recruitment has decreased by 8% and 9% for international students, contrasting with a 2% increase for English institutions.
  * The change in student support arrangements for EU students is seen as a temporary perturbation, while the Anglocentric nature of the media may affect the attractiveness of Welsh institutions.
  * Pay and pension costs, particularly the potential increase in costs related to the universities superannuation scheme pension fund, are significant pressures.
  * Increased student expectations for modern facilities and infrastructure bring capital expenditure and borrowing pressures.
  * The uncertainty around potential consequences from the review in England of fees and funding (the Augar review) is another pressure.
  * The HE sector is facing challenges in maintaining infrastructure and resources in the short term while awaiting the implementation of the Diamond recommendations.
  * The sector is responding to Brexit uncertainty by exploring additional sources of funding, strengthening marketing efforts, and making arguments to the UK government for maintaining access to funding sources.
  * Universities are preparing for various scenarios, including potential changes to Erasmus+ funding, by incorporating international mobility plans into their fee and access reports.
  * The HEFCW is monitoring institutions' financial forecasts and scenarios, challenging where necessary to ensure they are adequately prepared for the challenges ahead.

<summary>
• The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) has observed a decrease in EU student applications to Welsh institutions, contrasting with a 2% increase in England. 
• The main pressures on the Welsh higher education sector include funding, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, capital expenditure, and uncertainty around the implications of the Augar review in England.
• HEFCW is monitoring the financial forecasts of institutions, which anticipate a decrease in EU student income and an increase in costs related to Brexit, pensions, and student expectations.
• Institutions are planning for various scenarios, including potential reductions in EU student recruitment, by revising fee and access plans, enhancing marketing efforts, and seeking additional sources of funding.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to prohibit all forms of physical punishment of children.
• The Bill's purpose is to protect children's rights and ensure they have the same protection from physical punishment as adults.
• The Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, Julie Morgan AM, acknowledges that there are differing views on the Bill.
• The Bill is based on the understanding that physical punishment is incompatible with children's human rights.
• The Deputy Minister believes that the law should not define acceptable ways of hitting or punishing children, as it sends a confusing message.
• The Bill is supported by many people, including professionals who work with children.
• The Bill is part of a wider package of support for children and their parents, including parenting campaigns and services.
• The Welsh Government is committed to collecting data and monitoring the impact of the Bill.
• The Bill's implementation will involve an awareness campaign, an implementation group, and work streams addressing various issues.
• The Deputy Minister is open to considering amendments to the Bill to address concerns raised during the consultation process.
• The Bill's effectiveness is expected to be evaluated through ongoing monitoring and surveys.
</summary>

* The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to clarify and strengthen children's rights.
  * Witnesses from the Association of Directors of Social Services, Association of Directors of Education Wales, and Welsh Local Government Association support the Bill.
  * The current law is ineffective and unclear, according to the UN, as it still allows for the defense of reasonable punishment.
  * The rights of the child are fundamental, as outlined in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.
  * The Bill aligns with the Rights of Children and Young Persons (Wales) Measure 2011, which prioritizes the best interests of the child.
  * The Bill is seen as a natural progression in promoting children's well-being and rights in Wales.
  * Social services view the Bill as bringing clarity to the ambiguity in how children are cared for.
  * The Bill is expected to improve children's positions within their families by removing the defense of reasonable punishment.
  * The Bill's implementation will require resources for awareness-raising, training, and support services for parents.
